It is wise to establish trade while others only consider it.
Excellent! Your discovery will speed our victory!
I'm sure that will fetch a fine price at the bazaar, my friend.
It is a fine explorer that feeds his people. But beware the choke-cherries.
My explorer is more diplomat than outdoorsman, I would be honored if your explorer tutored him.
Take it. My people say, 'Let your neighbor be well off, for then he will not ask you for anything.'
A native American warrior will be a great aid to you.
Your compassion for the helpless will return to us in time.
Your explorer has a good eye for the exotic woods found here.
Your alliances with the native people will serve us well.
Eat and drink with your friends, but do not trade with them. Present company excluded, of course.
I have this advice for your walls -- measure a thousand times; cut once.
Remember, small keys unlock big doors. And cannon. Cannon work also.
My emissaries have secured the first alliance with the native Americans.
This land is in need of dates and silks. I will sell Ottoman luxuries in the wilderness.
This land is vast and full of wonders.
Hmm ... this New World could prove lucrative after all.
Exotic Food for my new colony. Did I warn you about choke-cherries?
My apologies. This explorer is young and eager. He will not gather treasures on your doorstep again.
My explorer is swift and keen-eyed. But I'm sure there are still treasures for you to claim.
A native American warrior. He will be a great help to my efforts.
There is much to learn, but each settler builds a piece of the Ottoman Empire.
There is little wood in our architecture; still, this wood is useful.
The sincerity of my words draws more allies to our alliance.
Our enemy has glutted the markets with baubles and trash. Now all will see superior Ottoman goods.
I am building a wall around my colony. An open door is an invitation to the viper.
A red apple invites stones. Our prosperity will make us a target. We must prepare.
Sorrow is to the soul what the worm is to wood. Do not let your losses eat at you.
Stairs are climbed step by step. Though you appear to have leapt them two by two.
You have seen many battles since we last met. Let us win this one together.
There is still time for me to pull victory from the lion's mouth.
We persevered, and so we shall be rewarded.
It is the aunt or uncle of all battles!
No matter how tall a tree grows its leaves always fall to the ground.
A dog that intends to bite does not bare its teeth. I will remember this for next time.
It is more difficult to contend with oneself than the world. This defeat is my own.
You are a worthy enemy. I will stop underestimating you.
You turned my attacks as the moon turns the tide. I must rethink my strategy.
I have learned from this battle. Do not expect that you will win another.
You have won a great victory, but as rain does not soak marble, you will not defeat me.
Bah ... I would have won that engagement, but you made me spill coffee on my robes.
You lose. A donkey is a donkey even when he is finely saddled.
Try not to get too much blood on my robes. They are Oriental silk. Very expensive.
If anyone weeps for you, it will be your mother; others will only pretend to weep.
A man becomes experienced by being defeated; a scholar, by making mistakes. I think you must be very learned.
Beauty passes, wisdom remains. You must be very wise to have stolen victory from me.
He who would gather honey must bear the sting of bees.
Your soldiers are in disarray. Their leader sounds an uncertain trumpet.
Sorrow is to the soul what the worm is to wood.
The battle is turning. The cock that crows too early gets his head cut off.
Only your ally saved you this time. Next time you will not be so fortunate.
You Age up quickly, but every man has his own way of eating yogurt.
What flares up fast, extinguishes soon.
Your Native Allies will make no difference in the end.
If you have something to say to me, say it in my town and leave my allies out of this.
You will pay for what you have done.
Relish your victory, but know that the liar's candle will only last until evening.
Yet once again we see that beauty passes. Wisdom remains.
You grow lethargic in the first Age. For the lean ox, there is no knife.
Are you still competing, or have you gone off to compose music?
To the snake that does not bite me, may he live a thousand years.
Do not roll up your trousers before reaching the stream.
The fly in a hurry falls into the milk.
Oh, I forgot about you. Are you still in this fight?
Two camels fight and the fly in between dies. You will be crushed.
You are miles away from your ally. You have no hope.
You are alone ... a sheep separated from the flock.
You huddle together like baby chickens!
That is quite enough of that!
Suleiman the Magnificent pronounces this colony unfit. Resign now, and you may leave in peace.
This building offended me, so I have destroyed it.
Watch your tongue when you speak to me. Sharp vinegar only damages its container.
You will harvest what you sow.
The fly is small, but it can upset your stomach.
There is no rose without a thorn, nor contest without a rival.
A weapon is an enemy, even to its owner.
A thousand friends are too few; one enemy is too many. You will learn the truth of this soon.
I see you enjoy a challenge. Then I shall give you one.
Yes, I was too much for you last battle. I will go easier on you this time.
Very well, we shall try again.
You bit off more bread than you could swallow last time. Perhaps this time will go better for you.
You leap into a sea full of sharks!
A daring rescue that will be the subject of a hundred poems.
I have looked into the eyes of my enemy and I do not like what I see there.
I see your soldiers. Do not think they are hiding.
Is this a raid? Are you sure you are ready? I will not go easy on you.
The hare was angry at the mountain, but the mountain was unaware of it. Your army is meaningless.
You prey on those who cannot defend themselves. There is no honor in that.
An army that size ... I suspect they do not bring tidings of your imminent surrender.
In case your runners have been lost. Your army has strayed into my territory. I would advise you to withdraw.
Suleiman the Magnificent will not forget how you attacked this colony.
Ah ... a scouting party. A wise man speaks of what he sees.
There is no need for a guide to a village which is visible.
I see your colony, there. I told my cartographers not to bother adding it to their map.
A bird steals bread from beneath the nose of the unwary.
Better to die on an empty stomach than live on an empty one. You have eaten, yes?
A single misfortune is better than a thousand warnings!
A good man will appear when talked about. You must have said my name.
He who steals a minaret prepares a case for it.
When you are an anvil, be patient; when you are a hammer, be strong.
A carefree head is only found on a scarecrow.
I admit defeat. Will you accept my surrender?
I have struggled against you long enough. Shall we call this finished?
Enough! You have won. I will resign if you will permit me.
Thorns and roses grow on the same tree. The rose you have found will soon show you its thorns.
Do not think Suleiman is blind to the tendrils you spread across the New World.
Your explorer is eager. He better watch out for bears. And janissaries.
I am sure news of your discovery will make all the effort worthwhile.
I think I heard a clinking of coin into your coffers. Spend it wisely.
Be careful of the Food in this New World. Especially the choke cherries.
Send my compliments to your explorer for his collection of unusual vermin and weeds.
Stay away from my town. The sheep separated from the flock gets eaten by the wolf.
Native Americans know these lands well, I curse that I did not find him before you did.
You will have need of every settler you have when I begin my attacks.
You should use that wood to build a boat and sail home. Or perhaps I can loan you a swift Ottoman Galley.
Build defenses if you must, but an over-protected eye always gets the speck.
Do you forget I am Ottoman? I will bring artillery to knock down your silly walls.
My skillful diplomats have forged alliance with the natives here while you ignore them.
The wealth of the Ottoman Empire is built on trade. Why should the New World be different?
All the New World is Suleiman's to explore.
If you could only see how much wealth we have amassed!
I fly in like a hawk to grasp a treasure right under your nose.
You seem to be having trouble finding treasures. Would it help if I pointed them all out to you?
The Ottomans accept people of all cultures into our glorious Empire.
More population for the Ottoman Empire!
I will use this wood to make more buildings for the Ottoman Empire.
It will not be long before the native Americans see your true treachery.
No one will want the worthless trinkets you peddle at your trade post
My armies will crush the victory you seek. But where will they strike?
There are now many places you must defend. But where will Suleiman attack?
My victory is inevitable. Surrender and I will treat you and your soldiers to a feast in my colony.
The moment of my victory approaches. I can hear the bombards sounding.
I see you have learned that every downhill has an uphill. And every uphill, a downhill.
I hear your name in the whispers of conquered foes. I would watch your back.
You have fought more battles since last we met. My tent is lined with banners of experienced leaders like you.

Beefeater: No, the gin was named after us, you see.
Beefeater: Had to work 22 years to earn the right to wear this hat.
Beefeater: We're granted an extra ration of beef, see?
Beefeater: No, I will not pose with tourists.
Jack: I've never even been to Whitechapel.
Jack: No, you've got the wrong guy.
Jack: Nobody goes to the East End.
Jack: There are those who call me... Graeme.
Strelet: Where were you last Tuesday night?
Strelet: We have ways of making you talk.
Strelet: The Czar is watching you.
Strelet: Nyet, I've not seen Anastasia.
Strelet: We don't call him The Terrible for nothing.
Strelet: You are going to be disappeared.
Strelet: No, I'm Boris. He's Ivan.
Hunchback: I gets to ring the bell.
Hunchback: I like to say hi to the pretty ladies.
Hunchback: My friends call be Quasi.
Hunchback: They had to cut my benefits.
Hunchback: Wait, this isn't Notre Dame.

Napoleon can be ambitious to the point of rudeness. He adapts his strategy to the situation, but prefers to attack with large armies of fully upgraded units, especially cavalry. He taunts his enemies frequently and may not follow his allies' lead.
Queen Elizabeth can be aloof, aristocratic and formal. She is a dependable if not overly warm ally. She understands the value of a strong economy and a versatile navy.

Queen Isabella of Castille is supportive bordering on flirtatious with her allies but mocks and chastises her enemies. She makes full use of the versatility of the Spanish army, but never leaves her colonies undefended. She is unlikely to take dangerous risks.

Ivan the Terrible is ruthless, sinister and threatening. He taunts enemy and ally alike. He likes to attack early and swarm his opponents with infantry and emphasizes large armies at the expense of technological development.

Maurice of Orange is all business. Every conversation is a transaction and every decision revolves around profit. He views war as a necessary part of business. He looks for Trade Routes when possible, but always defends his colonies.

Henry the Navigator is calculating and far-sighted. He emphasizes exploration and economic development over military dominance. He can take offense easily and can be something of a zealot when dealing with non-Portuguese.

Frederick the Great is proud and confident. He expresses regret when his men die in battle, but does not hesitate to use his entire military might to accomplish even the smallest task. Frederick will not neglect his economy, but believes in attacking aggressively.
Suleiman the Magnificent is scholarly and even-tempered. He balances colony development, trade, improvements and military. He is gracious to allies but may underestimate opponents.
Aristocrat: I can see how you think that might be better.
Aristocrat: I have heard you feedback, and ignored it.
Girl: Mommy, where do babies come from?
Artist: This piece? I call it man with no job.
Torchy: I might look good, but I have burns on two-thirds of my body.
Butcher: They call me Schwettie. Care for a famous Schwettie sausage?
Nice Lady: And now the money just rolls in.
Beefeater: No, no, I'm a vegetarian.
Jack: That's not a razor. This is a razor!
Policeman: Let me introduce you to Billy. Billy club!
Strelet: The health plan's not good, but I do get to beat people up.
Strelet: My five brothers were all strelets too.
Strelet: I come from a family of seventy. We're all strelets.
Vendor: Come and get your cookies. Cheap. Slightly used.
Vendor: You break it, I break you.
Vendor: Turnips! Fresh turnips! Old ones too.
Vendor: Eel! Get your fresh eel right here!

The Fraunhofer IIS MPEG Layer-3 Codec (l3codecx.ax) cannot be found on this computer. It is a required component of Microsoft DircectShow, and is required for proper sound playback in Age of Empires III. Please quit out and reinstall this codec before continuing. If you choose to continue, an alternative audio codec may be used which may cause problems including choppy sound, missing sound, delayed sound and possible game crashes.
